newsitem.title: USA: Ukrainian sees accord on Black Sea fleet.
newsitem.headline: Ukrainian sees accord on Black Sea fleet.

text.p: Ukrainian Foreign Minister Hennady Udovenko said on Tuesday he believes an agreement on the Black Sea fleet could be signed with Russia next month.
"Negotiations are taking place almost every day," he told reporters during an appearance at the National Press Club.

"Negotiations will continue this week and we hope by mid-November that we will expect a visit by (Russian Prime Minister Viktor) Chernomyrdin to Ukraine and he will be able to sign an agreement," Udovenko said.

Relations between the two ex-Soviet republics have long been dogged by a dispute over control of the Black Sea fleet, based in the port of Sevastopol, which has prevented them from signing a friendship treaty.
Russia's Duma, or lower house of parliament, last week urged the Kremlin to halt the long process of splitting the fleet, a move immediately denounced by the Ukrainian parliament.
Udovenko said on Tuesday that "fortunately the decision of the Duma is not supported by the Russian executive and the negotiations go on."
He reiterated that Ukraine "is not going to join NATO" but wants to work out a "special partnership" with the Western alliance.
Udovenko was in Washington for talks with U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher and other senior officials.
